title: "You're support. You don't matter."
body:
Yeah. Way to belittle the important, yet least respected and increasingly rare role. The one guy who is most likely to actually give a damn about your well being, and you crap all over them. This is the kind of treatment of supports get that causes the role to be in so short supply. You treat them like they are nothing but a playable minion and ward mule. Gee, I wonder why no one wants to be the support, then!?

By the way, this wasn't in just one or two games. I heard this about fifty times this week **alone**. So congratulations. You're continuing to contribute to a negative environment that has finally started to affect you, and the best and worst part is you don't even realize you're doing it or that it's even affecting you. I wonder what you're going to do once you render the entire role extinct? You think game imbalance is bad NOW? We're the ones locking down all the Udyrs and Xins. Once we're gone, you are going to REALLY see what it's like to get fucked.

IF OVER 92% OF ALL PLAYERS ARE NEUTRAL OR POSITIVE, WHY DO A LOT OF MY GAMES SEEM TOXIC?
_Players who are generally positive or at least neutral can have a bad day or week for any reason. If these players happen to be playing League of Legends when they feel frustrated or upset, they may be less likely to tolerate mistakes from fellow summoners, and start to rage or flame their teammates. As there are another nine players in the same match, any number of those players could become frustrated by a single summoner’s behavior, and will now have the potential to become a negative force in their own future games, causing the toxicity to spread, fast._

You and I have very different experiences of this game.

I encounter toxic players periodically, and I report them when I do.  It's been a while since I've seen one though.  
Maybe it's because I mostly ignore chat, have /all chat disabled, maintain a 1 strike mute policy and I limit my own communication to 'good job', 'thanks' and pings.  Also, if you add someone to your 'block' list, it mutes them in pre- and post-game as well as in-game.  So that's how I deal with toxic players in champ select.  Post game I just leave.  
Maybe it's because I play predominantly draft/team-builder/dynamic Normal queue.

That said, in comparison with other games in this genre Riot is much more pro-active about player behavior.  Not like it's a particularly high bar to beat, however they do put significant effort into it.

I definitely feel bad for jungle mains, you guys take so much shit for games that are being lost when the blame is not yours to bear. My duo partner is a jungle main, I've seen countless times laners push up to the enemy turret, get destroyed, come back to lane, and do the same thing like 3 or 4 more times. Then after they've fed {{champion:238}} or {{champion:114}} or some other super snowbally champ, they complain that the jungler hasn't come to their lane. Other times all 3 lanes will be pushed to the towers and the jungler will be doing everything they can to gank 1 lane to get them ahead, then some other lane will complain that jungler isn't winning their lane for them because they picked {{champion:157}} into {{champion:75}} .

I have to be honest, I don't actually know what the jungler's job is (this is due to the fact that I never get to play this role). If I had to take a guess I would say objective control. That being said, I know what's NOT the jungler's job, winning someone's lane for them. People often seem to think it's the jungler's job to spoon feed them so they can stomp their lane. It's also irritating when people expect you to gank every 10 seconds pre 6 with a champion that doesn't have good ganking power until 6, for example {{champion:131}} or {{champion:19}} . I've also seen too many times where a jungler's camps are being invaded and they ping for help but none of the lanes want to leave to come help them. It's ok when the jungler is losing blue/red buff but god forbid a laner misses a cannon minion.

So to all the jungle mains out there, for all the stolen dragons/barons, for all the ganks, and for protecting our turret when we need to recall, thank you for having our backs!
-Vaz-

What a Junger's role SHOULD be is to fill out a need for your team.  Bot/mid lane isn't the best for peeling away from lane to secure objectives like dragon early?  Grab someone who can do so.  Your team needs a hard frontline, grab one of the tanks that can do so.  Top/support is going tank, but you still need a bruiser?  Grab one of those.  Your frontline is good, but you need an assassin/carry?  Those can work too.  You have lanes that can snowball easy, they just need a kill or two ahead to get rolling?  Grab someone who can fill out what they need (as in damage or cc, probably the cc).  So in this sense, they are a lot like supports, in  that they should be working with their team to shore up it weaknesses, but they have more flexibility in the sense that they can fill in more weaknesses, because they do have a steady source of xp/gold income, so they can play item based carries.

One of the major things that junglers need more than anything is speed.  If it's just high mobility, fast clear times, or great dueling potential for those who counterjungle  (IE: fast champion kill times). These are the marks of a good champion for jungling, and knowing your champions strengths and weaknesses is key.  There are champions who don't have any of these that are good junglers, but they bring something else to the table that is stronger than their lack of speed, usually in the form of being healthier than others once they do a full or partial clear of their jungle.

Because of the speed, and their "lane" wanders across almost half the map, they were expected to, the same way that a support is, to put up vision, and to recognize and exploit mistakes from the opponents.  This really gets me going for both the role of support and the role of jungle, because apparently you are supposed to have pro level of threat/weakness recognition, and the split second reactions/mechanical execution to respond to these situations.  When I'm playing with people at my level, I'll make the same mistakes, same misclicks, same poor shot calls as them, but because of my play immediately affecting them instead of say, 5-10 minutes from now when my lane opponent decides to roam after they were just a better player and won the lane, they react instantly.

Funny enough maining {{champion:267}} and {{champion:89}} support is what got me out of Bronze last season. Went all the way from B3 to S5 with probably 80% of my games as support and half of those as Leona. I won probably about 60% of those matches. I found that when I was in a carry role half the time even if I won my lane the rest of my team would get stomped to dust. Things went much better when I was able to spoon feed them with well placed CC, or waiting for Zeds to ult and landing a bubble right as they come out of it. Often times I would have no boots and 6 active items and I'd be throwing shields, buffs, and cleanses all over the place. People don't realize it, but the insane amounts of utility that supports bring to the table can turn the tides of teamfights when placed in the right hands. I was always taught that the support's job is to maximize your team's potential in fights, and a good support can carry a team this way. I'm always asking myself "What champion can I pick to maximize the power of this team comp?" or "What items do I need to build to keep things in our favor?"

Although this season, because of how bursty everyone is and how quickly teamfights go, I haven't been doing so good. There's so little time to react to anything anymore that people die faster than I can heal them, or cleanse debuffs, hell even shields from {{item:3190}} {{item:3401}} feel pretty weak half the time. Building armor is almost pointless because everyone either does %hp true damage or has armor pen on every single item. Can't really build damage either because most support champions have god awful scalings. I feel like playing support this season just sucks, the only supports that really stand a chance in this meta are super tanks like {{champion:12}} and {{champion:201}} . There's a few other supports that are viable too, but {{champion:40}} has been meta for years and {{champion:432}} might as well be in the same class as taking a mid laner for support. With the gold and xp gap combined with how quick fights are I feel like the only things I'm ever good for anymore is being a ward machine, a distraction, or setting up a few kills early game. Once it gets to mid game though it feels like everything is out of my hands. I feel like my skill level peaked around mid to late season 5, then ever since I've just been playing worse or something. Support just isn't that fun anymore, I really hope Riot gets around to a support update or something.

Cheers to all the support mains out there who continue to take up the burden!
-Vaz-

Assuming you're ruling out all the flex picks like Poppy, Lulu, Lux, Nunu and Nautilus from the category of "support champs".  Trundle has seen some high level support play too.

Considering most non-flex supports have been nerfed specifically to keep them out of solo lane and/or jungle viability *at least* once, some several times... yeah, it's not surprising that their current balance state is not solo lane viable.  When you have a kit that is great at working with others you often have a kit that is bad at working without others -- or Riot will nerf you until you do.

On the other hand, when you have a map where grouping happens constantly and everyone is assured a decent gold income whether their champion last hits well or not, i.e. ARAM... then most supports are top tier or outright OP even *after* the map-specific nerfs to sustain, and this is only partly concealed by the fact that you can't pick them on purpose.

The laning phase doesn't create 1 slot where supports are good so much as it creates 3-4 slots where supports are bad, hiding how strong their kits truly are at equal gold and exp.
